lexUnit.name: bluster.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: talk in a loud, aggressive, or indignant way with little effect

sentence.text: ` I never heard such nonsense , " he blustered .
` Oh , just a hole , " he blustered .
` I do n't care what he says , " I blustered .
` I made no promise to Malachi , " he blustered .
` Do n't listen to him , " Witcher blustered .
` You had no right to do this , " he blustered .
` Christ , I shall be glad when we can get back to real news " he blustered .
“ I do n't know what you 're talking about … ” he blustered , turning to face her , trying not to acknowledge what he saw written on her face .
` We may not choose to come , " he blustered .
` No one can prove anything , " blustered O'Hara .
` That 's scarcely the point , " blustered the American .
` I was trapped into it ! " blustered the tenor .
He blustered that he was a dealer in pictures , not a criminal .
He started blustering about the general election and an end to the inflationary spiral .

He liked to think of Beamish in the dock at the Central Court , his counsel blustering on about his client 's perfectly normal , acceptable need for heavy metal poisons ( ‘ But how do you explain , Mr Beamish , your ordering a quantity of thallium from a perfectly reputable chemist 's … ? ’ )
He blustered and turned scarlet as if caught out in a crime , and tried to bluff it out , but I knew him too well .
Charles blustered and looked affronted for a moment while he took this in .
He was blustering , saying the first thing that came into his head .
